title: How was the ambience for the Role Selection lobby made?
body: I amped up my volume to a hundred and it was really soothing to listen to for a moment. Quite tranquil. I wonder if it was just recorded in some forest or is it a compilation of multiple sounds?

replies.body:
Hey there! This ambient bed was created using some of the real-world recordings we used for the Summoner's Rift background ambiences, mixed with  elements of our homegrown Runeterra "blue magic" sound FX palette.

Thanks for the comment - glad you like it =)
What's in that recipe for "blue magic"? Where do you use it? I must know what this means!

It's a combination of fighter jet bys slowed waaaaaaaaaaay down, (like way down...) heavily reverbed wind chimes, a touch of heavily reverbed and washed out choir samples and slowed down fire whooshes.

That stuff gets used a lot on the SR Order side crystal elements, (Nexus energy, Turret magic) as well as any blue magic you see in the League Client, as well as in stuff like the graphic transitions on Champ Spotlights, etc. =)
Oh thanks! Nice to know not all of it is literally a synthetic mix even though i wouldn't mind it at all it's quite relaxing when amped up.

Riot doesn't seem to use a lot of actual real world recordings for this type of thing. They typically mix and edit various studio-recorded sound effects to get what they want. The bird calls might just be an edited existing sound bite, while the magical noises would be made using some combination of real world stuff in a studio.
Depends. It would be very easy to just get natural noises from...well, nature. I don't see why they would want to complicate things by doing it all artificially.

> [{quoted}](name=LightTrack,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=lpmi4cj2,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2018-05-05T06:28:12.875+0000)
>
> Depends. It would be very easy to just get natural noises from...well, nature. I don't see why they would want to complicate things by doing it all artificially.

Not as easy as you think! There's all sorts of extra background noise to contend with, and the birds don't really comply with your recording equipment and call at your command, so real nature doesn't necessarily sound like the cleaned-up version in the client. :P
Well fair point but exceptions do occur in some places. I doubt it's all just white noise. Maybe they simply filtered out large parts of the actual recording to make it sound smoother.
